text: Any1 has a lot experience with / knowledge of Mosby MVP lib?
Any  recommendations article, tutorial or video explaining about proguard ?

Yeah let me write one:

> don't use proguard
Joking aside lots of people will recommend you to not use it unless you absolutely have to
But it shouldn’t stop anyone from learning about it a bit
Well yes but my personal recommendation is to not use it unless someone has to
and really anything from here should suffice <https://medium.com/search?q=proguard>
<@U0WS24HNH|john_nhat> has joined the channel
wohh can you explain me , why don't use that ?
It creates a lot of problems and you will have to be constantly on guard on whether proguard is what messed up your build
i think proguard useful for obfuscating android code
I usually use proguard without issues
except currently where a good part of the app is still unrefactored so I can’t risk using it

We have an open source SDK which we use in the main app and we were trying to figure out for a couple of days why we suddenly got NPEs everywhere after an SDK update. It turned out that Proguard just messed up the naming causing a lot of problems
:open_mouth:
was it with models not serialising properly?
It's a very specific to us issue, but I will just never forget the face of my coworker trying to solve that bug. I was scarred from when I saw his face
:joy:
I haven’t had any proguard bug that was _that_ bad
<@U0548MM6B>: I don't really remember anymore because it was some time back and my coworker solved it
I know most bugs I’ve had were either not adding proper rules or not adding @SerializedName / having proguard ignore the models

MVP question: Do you use different data structures for every "view" screen even if you use the same data? 

For example let's take a Reddit client where you have a NavigationDrawer showing the subreddits names only and a "DetailedSubredditView". In the first case, you have a "GetAllSubredditsUseCase" which will return you a simplified data structure for the subreddits for the NavigationDrawer, so in this case it will hold just the name and an id. In the second case you will have a "GetSubredditDetailsUseCase" which returns a data structure with every possible details that the user would care to see.

So one way is doing that, for every view have a different data structure tied to a different use case. Another way is to have only one data structure passed around in the presentation layer and use from that structure whatever you need at whatever screen.

Which would be preferable? I see the benefits of completely different data structures but I feel that someone could end up with a gazillion of them + data mappers like _SubredditEntityToNavigationDrawerEntityMapper_ and _SubredditEntityToSubredditDetailEntityMapper_

Honestly, depends on the backend a lot and what the API is returning.
We mostly use a simplifed model + more detailed one but they share some base stuff like id, title and some boolean values.
I’d go with having a same model where you can

That's what I'm thinking as well. To have one model that encapsulates the most information I would ever show to the user. The issue that I see though is that changing that one model will affect a lot of screens
the backend though is defined by me, I am in full control
basically my repository gets a data structure that has everything -> passes that to the use cases -> the use cases map it to something nice -> the presenter gets something nice

It really depends on the use case of the particular model, like for all subreddits without details, I’d just use a simple list of with <name,id> and if I need a ton of subreddits with details, I’d use a more detailed model.
but changing one detailed model shouldn’t affect other screens :thinking_face:
I thought you meant to use the detailed model data structure everywhere and just use the getters that I need
so in the NavDrawer I would use `getId()` and `getName()` and in the detailed I would have `getId()`, `getName()`, `getNumberOfSubscribers()` etc

Mostly everywhere, so like the detailed model would share a model with some other stuff that requires more detail - specific subreddit view, another subreddit list which would show details, some “top subreddits” thing and stuff like that. So where you can and same stuff is needed, no need to separate models.

I'd do that mostly due to speed of backend fetching - we had issues with some field in our models being slower to fetch, so initial load time would be bigger and in case someone else comes along for the ride in development and decides “oh I need to show number of subscribers here” he calls something that’s doesn’t exist or returns null. If that isn’t the case there, I see no reason not to go with the same model.
For me it really depends on the use case and on the API

Alright I believe I get what you mean and it makes sense. So basically even use cases could be the same so if we had like you said a list of just the names of the subreddits and another list of the subreddits where we also show the subscribers, then we have just one use case "GetAllSubredditsUseCase" which just returns the full structure in both cases instead of having two different use cases with two different data mappers and two different data structures
damn that sucks… thanks for looking though <@U0546QERR>
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QdmkXL7XikQ>
was looking forward to that talk.
finally!
<@U053PPGDC>: :taco:
cheers <@U09T8SFG8>
I finally understand the difference between map and flatmap :joy:
why can't you set android:selectAllOnFocus="true" on and EditTextPreference and have it select all text when you pop that preference?
EditTextPreference just relays its attributes to the underlying EditText, so not sure
what are the best business rules to do form validation?
<http://i.imgur.com/Nei7LXN.gif>
should you do validation as you type to display an error, until the field is valid
should you wait until a submit button is clicked to then validate
should you disable a submit button until all fields are valid
not that gif, that's for sure
or is there some other strategy
validating after first focus, if the field is not empty
and `.debounce(1000, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)`
another strategy i have seen is when you move from one input field to the next then it starts doing validation
so debounce will just mean , if you stopped typing for 1000 miliseconds (1 second)
then the user has paused and now its time to validate
yeah, one of my favorite rxjava operators
it only emits after not receiving subsequent emissions for the time period
and how are you checking after first focus?
would probably require either a custom view or just maintaining a flag for that field elsewhere and update it with onFocusChanged
i've done debounce but not the first focus thing personally
so i guess can you explain the first focus thing with more words
im not exactly clear what you mean by that
i would allow the user to focus on that field and type whatever they want the first time, but after focus is removed do the validation
and in combination with the debounce logic that would allow them to fix their mistake without getting nagged too much
so you are saying, the first time they start typing in that field
even if they stopped typing for 1 second
but still have focus on the field
it wouldn’t show an error if the field was invalid
but ...
for credit card that makes a lot of sense because people don't type that from memory usually
I don’t bother checking for first focus
instead I skip the initial (blank) result
finally
if they click on another field it would show an error
or if they give focus to another field and then come back to the first field
it will now show errors after 1 second of not typing
that was the experience i had in mind yes :simple_smile:
interesting
so debounce throttles the error messages
and the first focus thing, further throttles error messages
yeah, the whole validation process really
so how about this ...
if you are using debounce and it has waited 1 second
and then the field is invalid so it shows an error
as soon as you continue typing does the error go away or does it stay until you correct it
im asking because ...
if you are trying to correct the invalid field would you really want to see that its still an error
or only see that its an error once you stop typing
that would be a fairly easy enhancement to the stream, and it sounds good
just add some logic upstream of debounce to remove the error message
the order of operations in an rxchain, im guessing, really matters
yep, if you add it after debounce you wouldn't remove the error until you validate again
which wouldn't work
okay
thanks, im glad you are so familiar with rx
im getting the hang of it
but only after reading dozens of blogs
i remember there were some nuances with the threading around debounce that you have to be aware of
why don’t you just filter it for the length before debounce? you know CC field will have N numbers
so that gif was for demonstration purposes
i was speaking more in general, but yeah that's good for CC numbers
im actually not using CC for my purposes
oh :smile:
it will probably just be email and password

im having trouble getting debounce to work
<https://gist.github.com/lawloretienne/c695ef5585a5027ae6afae3ba07ed716>
with the debounce() method added to the rxchain, instead of it waiting 600 ms after the last character was typed and then proceeding down the chain
it appears that it never gets down to the onNext() method of the Subscriber
however if i comment debounce() out of the chain
then i do see it get to the onNext() method of the Subscriber
am i wiring up debounce the wrong way?
hmm... that seems to be similar to how i've done it
you set a breakpoint and sure the onNext block isn't triggering?
ill try that

```_onTextChangedEvent =
		Observable.merge(_scoreEntryFields.map { RxTextView.textChanges(it) })
				.debounce(SCORE_CALC_DELAY, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS, AndroidSchedulers.mainThread())
_onTextChangedEvent.subscribe(
		{ _presenter.onScoreUpdated() },
		{ }, { })```
kotlin, but yeah. straight from my project
i just have `AndroidSchedulers.mainThread()` so view updates happen correctly
hmmm I use .debounce().map().filter().subscribe( onNext,OnError)
it might be you’re missing onError
yeah if you're accessing views from outside the main thread that would throw an error in onNext
oh i guess i havent explicitly set up the threads
for observeOn and subscribeOn
okay i think it is a threading issue
how do you print which thread you are currently on?
thread.current or something
Thread.currentThread().getName()
got it
that’s it :smile:
btw, one thing i learned from that rxjava talk: always implement onError :simple_smile:
good to know
even if it's just to rethrow the exception or print it, then you get nice stack traces from your own code instead of random rxjava stuff

so it looks like it was
currentThread - RxComputationThreadPool-3

so that is without specifying explictly
.observeOn(AndroidSchedulers.mainThread()) // UI Thread
looks like i need to add this to my rxchains
you can specify the scheduler in the overloaded method
interesting
always new stuff to learn when it comes to Rx
for sure
that moment when Rx becomes a bit less “voodoo magic"
/gif smiling kanye

<https://gist.github.com/lawloretienne/c695ef5585a5027ae6afae3ba07ed716>
